Go Proposal: Spec Update for Range Over Int and Range Over Func

2023/07/22
This article was written by an AI ðŸ¤–. The original article can be found here.

The Go programming language is constantly evolving to meet the needs of developers, and a recent proposal suggests adding two new types that a for-range statement can range over: integers and functions. This proposal aims to make iteration in Go more concise and expressive.

The proposal suggests that if an integer type is used, the for-range statement for x := range n { ... } would be equivalent to for x := T(0); x < n; x++ { ... }, where T is the type of n. This means that the loop will iterate from 0 to n-1, producing index iteration values of the same type as n. If n <= 0, the loop will not run any iterations. This addition simplifies loops that only require counting, making them shorter and easier to read.

Additionally, the proposal introduces range over function types. If f is a function type of the form func(yield func(T1, T2) bool) bool, the for-range statement for x, y := range f { ... } is similar to f(func(x T1, y T2) bool { ... }). The loop body is moved into the function literal, which is passed to f as yield. The boolean result from yield indicates whether to continue iterating. The boolean result from f itself is ignored in this usage but allows for easier composition of iterators. The proposal also notes that T1 and T2 are optional, allowing for functions with different parameter counts to be iterated over.

This proposal aims to make range the for loop form of choice for most iteration scenarios. By providing a simpler syntax for counting and allowing for iteration over function types, developers can write more concise and readable code. It is important to note that the control flow statements within the loop body retain their original meaning.

The Go community is encouraged to provide feedback on this proposal to ensure that it meets the needs of developers. The addition of range over int and range over func would be valuable enhancements to the language, making iteration in Go more powerful and flexible.
